On april 13, 2011
Kayin
You cannot unregister a dinoz after the registry period (which is 7 days) up to the rewards. And also you can't add spheres on it through the matchs course. Your dinoz levels (equipped spheres) are counted in some sort of formula to define its power factor.

This power factor is summed up with all of the other dinozs in your clan team. So your clan will only encounter another clan with approximatively the same clan power. So if your clan has only level 20, why not.

Yes the "level up" button will be locked, and so when you're reaching the max, you won't max out your bar. Only missions give over the maximum.

On april 14, 2011
Berelain
There is a other side also to look at:

example:
Say you can select 6 dino's each.

You select 3 lvl 50 and 3 lvl 10. With the calculations being made (dont know them exactly, just pointing out 1 thing) you apear a lot less strong then when you select more lvl 50.

Lets say its based on points.
50 x 3 = 150
10 x 3 = 30
30 + 150 = 180 points

180/6 = 30

So you can face with your lvl 50 and lvl 10, 6 lvl 30.

Your never planing to use the lvl 10 (scale maybe), but because you have lvl 10 with you, you can go against a clan with only lvl 30 dinoz.

It's a clan based championship, so lets say everyone in your clan has 3 lvl 50. A clan is based to have 50 members. So that's 50 x 3 = 150 lvl 50 dinoz. You only can use a few each time. So you have reserve. You never have to use your lvl 10. But your still facing a clan with only lvl 30, because you brought the lvl 10 with you.

To be realistic, no clan has 150 lvl 50 dinoz. But how many clans have lots of lvl 40+ dinoz? With taking low lvl dinoz with you, you get easier clans in front of you, then when you take your whole team with you.

Just a thought, to think about.

On april 14, 2011
[939518]
Rules in short:

Each clan will have a point, which will came from the top 200 dinoz in the team(only those count which has been enrolled before the start)

Spheres will count(2 spheres = +1 level) and the points of the dinoz will increasing exponentialy(app. a 6-7 level higher dinoz worth double the points of a dinoz)

And the best is that it will be a limit of how many points can be on the field in the same time, which will cut in half the advantage of the clan with the stronger dinoz!

On june 6, 2011
epoq
OK Guys,

Need some quick replies here if possible. I've just come out of a meeting with the developers, and we kinda came up with an idea for the new COTC which would be on trial here first, or may even be kept PURELY for us if everyone likes it.

As we know, this is going to be something of a test championship, so we're free to change almost everything about the configuration (within reason). So I thought, "How about a Hardcore, speed championship?"

I'm talking 7 battles, lasting 2 days instead of the previous 4, 1 rest day instead of 2. We're talking 1AP every 30 mins. 100 dinoz per team, and prizes allocated for the number of fights won - NOT the highest ranked at the end. (7 out of 7 = Napodinoz baby!!!)

The new system with the 'sliding' rankings will be in place, as will the "power ratings". level ups WILL be permitted during the championship too.

I'm pretty excited about this, and am really looking forward to your feedback! Let battle commence!

Epoq

ps. As usual, if you don't agree, please don't just say "that sucks - stoopid idea!", please give us an idea of what you want to see!

On june 6, 2011
zony
A system that gives 1 AP every 30 mins imo takes the fun out of the cotc for people, that can only be online some hours a day at a specific time. Ofc if the game is aimed at people who don't have regular work hours (or don't work at all) those people should be satisfied with such a speedy cotc. Everyone else should be disappointed. I agree, that the cotc is a bit slow from time to time, but on the other hand often enough one will be happy about the slow speed, since it gives fellow clan members a better chance to arrive just in time and help out their teammates.

reasons for disappointment:
- the time interval, in which the battle is decided, gets smaller
- times where people can't be online at all (work, night sleep, also depending on the time zone you are living in) get a greater influence; its harder to compensate those hours where many ppl were missing -> depending on time zone one clan might get favoured over the other... this effect existed in the past, but not as strong as if would be with this fast system
- people who can vary their times of sleeping or working are favoured tremendously and while I am not against favouring activity, imo this is too much

let me talk in extremes if one doesnt understand what I mean:
extreme number 1: 1 AP / 5 Minutes (and points awarded every 10 mins), 8 hours fighting length
Result:
- Clan with more active players for those 8 hours will win. (bad)
- easier to react to spontaneous actions from the enemy, since one only needs to watch the fight for 8 hours (good)

extreme number 2: 1 AP every day, points awarded every second day, fight lasting 96 days
result:
- Clan with better tactics and dinos will win (under the premise, that all players can be online once a day to do some actions together), the players' time zones won't have a great effect (good)
- harder (or rather frustrating) to react to spontaneous actions from the enemy, since you need to watch the fight a looong time, while almost nothing happens (bad)

So basically you need to find a mode between those two extremes, that favours active players (counter attacks etc), but still won't get you an auto-loss if your clan has some "black-out"-times where almost noone can fight the battle. Since those black-out times can vary from clan to clan it basically would be best to minimize the impact of such times, while still maintaining the flow of the battle. And 1 AP / 60 or 75 mins was ok for that IMO.

On june 7, 2011
ZenNukshuk
It is good to see the effort that Epoq and MT are putting into improvements to the game, and many thanks to them for asking the players for input .

This truly is an international game.

However
Having a system that discriminates against those in a particular time zone, or those that cannot be online every 4 hours, takes a lot away from this game.

1. If you want to be 'fair' to all time zones, make the difference in the start times more than 4 hours or have the start times go around the world in equal parts e.g., GMT, GMT-6, GMT-12, GMT-18 (=GMT+6).

2. If games are to be reduced in length, perhaps try 72 hours first (a real 3 days not ~3 days).

3. If you want to be 'fair' to all players/clans, including those with jobs that limit connecting times, the 30min system is a very bad idea. If the new direction is to have a faster game then perhaps try every 50 minutes first. Small steps, not radical changes, will help to determine what is best.

4. If you are making restrictions on who can play (effectively eliminating those that cannot play from work or are in unfortunate time zones) then also limiting the number of dinoz to 100 is just a further aggravation of this. Don't change too many elements at once

5. If you allow levelling up (and yes of course there will be some abuse) then at least don't allow spheres to be added after the registration period is over.

It will be interesting to see how this turns out

On june 13, 2011
Piemaster
I don't really have a strong opinion on whether or not announcements should always be posted on the game news page vefore Facebook.

However, I do know a bit about the industry and I know that most browser games took a big hit to their player base with the growth of 'Facebook games' such as Farmville, Mafia Wars etc. It wasn't that most of these games were particularly *good*, but they has a viral aspect that generated free advertising and referrals due to varying systems of encouraging players to invite their friends and spam their own and their friends Facebook profiles with game material for in-game advantages.

So now most of the existing games want to get in on the Facebook action to ensure growth and/or survival. Unfortunately most older games were not designed to interface with Facebook, but various things are being tried in different games including basic Facebook pages where game information is shared, Facebook apps for existing games and even side-games linked to the main game played on Facebook.

Note I have no inside contacts at MT and so have no idea how much of the above applies to DinoRPG, but that is what is happening across the industry as a whole.

Piemaster
One thing really bugs me about this pairing system. No, it's not the potential for being paired up with a clan we can't possibly beat, that's something that is going to happen virtually regardless of the pairing system used.

The problem is that if Epoqs description of how it works is accurate, there is zero incentive for actually taking on and beating a clan better than you. What if you do pull out the stops, spent a fortune on consumables, play a tactically perfect game and actually win. What would your reward be? Well accordig to Epoq's description, you would swap places with that better clan in the rankings! This would guarantee you impossible matchups for most of the rest of the tournament and make it extremely hard for you to win a prize, even though you may have got off to the dream 2-0 start or whatever.

Yes, you heard that right. If you draw up in the next round (or probably any of the 3 after that), winning would actually be *bad* for you. So the best thing you could do would be to surrender as soon as the match starts and not even bother enterring the battle field.

Hopefully your opponents won't have the same idea and click the surrender button before you do...

On june 28, 2011
Piemaster
you dont have to decide if both are good or bad, but you may still have an opinion of wich is better, respective the lesser evil
I don't know really, it's difficult to say.

First of all I think we need to establish what we are complaining about. I would say that everyone who is complaining that the +/- 6 differential in rankings is too big is really chasing rainbows. It is impossible to create a pairings system where everybody has a good matchup every round, (while still maintianing a semblence of fairness and progression). There will always be a lot of games that are completely one-sided, because the power disparity of clans on this server is so high. People claim the last CotC was better, but even though we played in the amateur league (which in theory should be the most evenly matched) in 12 games, only 3 of them were even a vaguely fair contest, not coincidently the QF, SF and Final. So if people are attacking this CotC on the basis that their clan just lost in a one-sided game, suck it up as that will never be fixed, regardless of whether we use this system, the old system, Swiss, triple elimination or whatever.

I think the last CotC had the problems that a very narrow subset of dinos could be used and that clans were rewarded for bottom-feeding in the lowest league possible. This CotC doesn't have those problems, but manages to break the fundamental rule of a tournament that winning should be better than losing.

Which is preferable? Meh, it's up to you.

On june 28, 2011
ReiNijs
To everyone who is saying that they didn't knew about "power cap".

You maybe forgot it same as I did, but once we reached that cap I remembered that support page was from the beginning saying that:
How is the maximum permissable power calculated during the battle?
This value relates to the average power of the Dinoz in the front lines of the 2 clans.
The first line, which is defined as the 45 most powerful Dinoz that could possibly take to the battlefield.
Therefore, in a battle between clan A and clan B, if the front line of clan A is worth 9000 and the front line of clan B is worth 11000, the maximum power authorised will be (9000+11000)/2, i.e. 10000.In the sample given you see that one clan will be able to put on slightly less but slightly stronger dinoz, while other slightly more but slightly weaker dinoz.

In real situation the difference between A and B was so huge apparently (lets say 30k against 10k with CnD putting only 9 while Polish put 26 and could probably put on more as I assume the power cap was higher than in va vs froggz).. I can only speculate.. but in any case if the power ranking table is correct than everyone has equal opportunities till someone run out of power to put on the table (like danish dino raiders). So if you give up without a fight it's your own fault that you dunno how to make your numbers count. Just image how much more off this scale would if we had not 100 team cap but 300. Some with 300 dinoz could get the same power as some with 30dinoz. So if they met as they should and would.. than one clan would have 1 dinoz on board while other had some 10.

On june 28, 2011
Piemaster
The first round is against a gap of 6 places, the second round will be against a gap of 5, until the last round which will be against the closest clan.

The gap is large, but it reduces. This means it IS worth trying to beat higher-ranked clans...

No, that's the very thing that makes it not worth it. If you beat a higher ranked clan in the early rounds that means you jump up to a much higher position and can get effectively 'locked in' there. In fact if the numbers work out badly for you it might mean that you don't get another winnable match for the rest of the tournament.

For example, imagine Dutch Brotherhood had beaten GDJ. Their next matches would likely be against C&D, BBC and LooT, which would immediately knock them competely out of napo contention. As a result of losing, their next matches will likely be against a variety of clans more their own level. Even if you get lucky with the pairings, the best you can hope for is to get paired 'down' against a team that was originally ranked higher than you. If we could turn back time I think a lot of clans (even some that were paired down) would have clicked surrender faster than you can say pixelwank once the first match started. Heck I'm not sure we might not have been better of surrendering to Czech Claws.

When I played tennis we had an interesting ranking system...maybe we could also think about something like this. A ranking which stays until the next tournament...that would also reduce the outlay for our admin. When a system like this is running properly it´s running...just like dojo

First time the ranking is made, there is a simple tournament, lottery-system. I don´t know how many would be needed here...maybe 5 rounds...then the ranking is made out of those matches with the wins/losses/draws and exact amount of points to make a ranking possible.

After that starts the real leauge-fun:
In the first round it starts with the last clan in the ranking which can decide to challenge any clan in the ranking. If the lower ranked clan wins, they switch ranks. This way it goes up the ranking.
In the next round we start this thing at a higher position. we did tournament matches 3 times a week with 23players, so it was always one player up...but in our case, I would assume ~10places up every round or something like this...you could also think about a special rule that f.e. a clan that has been challenged 3times in a row gets the chance to challenge another clan first...that would provide some clans from beeing challenged all the time.

I like this kind of ranking and we would have a permanent system!

Hi, guys!
I really liked DinoRampage's fight in the first round.
And now about the COTC so far.
Is it fun? - It is fun.
Is the ranking system good? - Yes, great idea! There is only Polish legacy's anomaly, but everything else is ok.
Is the pairing system (or tournament system) good? - Hm..
Pros: Fights still are versus close to your clan clans.
Everyone can get nice prizes.
You can test your dinoz against strong clan's team. Yay!
Contras: First 6 vs second 6, third with fourth... Switching places... WHoa!!! Strange!!!
It's really weird.
No bonuses for the good end spot so far (i.e. 1st, 2nd, 3rd places etc.)
Is the handicap system good (board power cap in a fight)? - Yes, it is unbalanced (only 9 dino for C&D? Power cap?), it's description in FAQ is not accurate, but the idea is good.

I would like to suggest McMahon pairing system for the next COTC. With like 5 or 6 MM starting groups and special prizes (epic + napo) for streak winners.
MM is appropriate here, because it was designed for tournaments with large power gaps between players. Perfectly fitting our situation.
NB: there could also be prizes for the best clan (by position at the end of the tournament) in every staring MM group.

Husaurus
To me the ideal CotC would scale the value of each win by the strength (power level) of the opponent. So the ideal strategy would be to fight the strongest opponent you can win against... which means a system could be set up where each clan challenges a set number of opponents... the top ranked clan chooses first, then on down the list. Then additional pairing could be made by Epoq to ensure everyone gets the same number of matches.
Like, 3 challenges made by you, up to 3 challenges to you from other members, and at least 3 more challenges assigned by Epoq.

If a clan chooses easy wins, they will be less likely to get a reward. If a clan chooses too difficult of opponents, they will be less likely to get a reward. If a clan pushes themselves, and fights well, they are more likely to get a reward.

It would definitely hurt clans like mine. However, I would like to see server statistic on the player population, and clan population... because real solutions for competitive events need real data. If there is a concrete stratification of clans that requires leagues, or multi-staged events, then more than guessing is needed.

There is clearly more than one type of clan. Are they ultimately differentiated by the number of paying players, or something unexpected? Are we trying to balance apples and oranges?

The best solution is probably something tangential to the same old reasoning we are throwing about. And it may be something as simple as there needs to be competitive events within clans, so there would be a counter-pressure to "just getting into the most powerful clan that will accept you"... If players have also to compete against their clan mates (and only their clan mates) in some events, then clans might naturally form into leagues based on an average player power level.

Well, that little bit of thinking makes me wonder... maybe clans in the CotC should not be rated on the power level of registered dinoz, but by the power level of their strongest player. And these power levels could be used to separate clans into leagues.

On july 1, 2011
[None]
Sorry, long post...

Has anyone suggested using the point values themselves to match the opponents.

Everyone starts with whatever the point value their donoz generated. Each battle would increase or decrease this value. Rather than a simple +1/-1, the increase or decrease would be based on power level difference, length of fight, point differential, etc. If a stronger clan beats a weaker clan they do not gain many points for it. If a weaker clan beats a stronger clan they would get a lot of points for it. It would even be possible for the weaker clan to gain points in a loss if they put up a good fight. The next round would again try to pair clans with similar points.

Base the prizes based on the number of points gained rather than wins after a set number of fights.

I am sure the idea could be fleshed out more, but that is the general idea...

So much about this game is about strategy and luck correct?

One could think a type of strategy for this type of event would be instead of placing 100 dinoz place only 30 dinoz so your power level would be less. Or instead of registering 20 level 40+ dinoz...only place a few superhigh leveled dinoz and keep them grouped together. Fill in the rest of the board with well leveled dinoz with no spheres which wont increase your power too high. You could also have players register certain dinoz based on their timezones...You could have only a certain type of dinoz enter the battlefield at one time...etc....

There are so many different options a clan leader could do that would raise or lower their clans power level. The option chosen dictated your rank and position for this clan event. PL are ranked where they are based on a strategy that they have chosen for this event which most likely involved registering their best dinoz for the event (else their rank would not be so high up). It is a type of strategy that ended up placing them in a poor rank combined with bad luck.


So next luck comes into play..either good luck or bad luck. Based on your strategy you would either be ranked favoribly or unfavoribly. If it was in your favor (IE playing against a clan ranked 6 places lower then you) then you were handicapped by how many dinoz can be placed at one time. This limitar makes defense a little bit more difficult when you do not have enough dinoz on the field to do what you want to do . If you recieved an unfavorable position then at least you can fight at full force.

I do admit this system seems flawed, and I honestly do not know how it will turn out, but I sort of feel your rank was dictated by each clan leader based on what type of dinoz were registered.

On july 3, 2011
Bengeldorn
I just got any crazy idea, which probably isn't fully thought-out.

I'll try to explain my idea as good as I can:

Each Battle is detirmed randomly, meaning that which clans fight each other isn't dependet on whach dinoz a clan could provide.

Before a battle starts there a 3 phases.

Phase 1: Opponent Announcment
The draw has resulted in the matchups, and each clan can see which clan it has to face.

Phase 2: Dino Selection
Each clan selects up to 100 Dinoz, it would like to use in the battle against the announced clan.
At any time each clan can see:
- ones own power
- the power of the opposite clan
- the amount of power which could be put on the field.

Phase 3: Power Adjustment
For (hopefully) ease of description, I'll define follwing:
Clan A, B; A != B
pA = Power of A, pB = Power of B; pA > pB
If pA = pB + (pB × 0.1) Then:
- End Dino-Selection-Progress for A and B
- Lock level-up and sphere-use on selected Dinoz for A and B
Else:
- End Dino-Selection-Progress for B
- Lock level-up and sphere-use on selected Dinoz for B
- A can adjust Dino-Selction to lower it's power, if it wants to
- After confirmation of A or a certain amount of time passed:
. - End Dino-Selection-Progress for A
. - Lock level-up and sphere-use on selected Dinoz for A

After that the battle between A and B starts normally, as we know it.


So the idea behind this, is not to have match-ups between clans, which normally would be close to each other, but to know prior a battle what is expacting you.

So if you don't have high level Dinoz, you will probably face either Dinoz of comparable level, but with also a comparable amount of Dinoz on the field, or you'll face higher leveled Dinoz, but fewer Dinoz on the field.
Either way you have a tactical possibility to win a fight.

Well just a rough thought I had.
If you do or don't like it, feel free to comment it or propose adjustments, or dangers I didn't thought through.

ROBlNHOOD, Round 4 Polish Legacy v Les Froggizs... the winner would normally face The Cookies in Round 5... BUT Froggizs v Cookies already happened in Round 2.
Here is the tricky part... Which team gets paired with Cookies instead. If it is GDJ, 'the next unmatched team (before Froggizs)'... DE v Rank 23 happens. The Polish Legacy could beat Froggizs, and there would be no bump (until maybe Round 6)... but the Polish Legacy already has three losses and are pretty much guaranteed a 4th loss, therefore Froggizs will fight harder because they can still win something. So I've been assuming a Froggizs win.

On july 7, 2011
Husaurus
JakeySnakey, making sweeping generalizations and condemning others according to "your thinking", and then attributing that to a judgement from some god is inappropriate.

Short term thinking is not synonymous with honor or nobility. Consider the following...
1. A lot of clans did not enter as many of their strongest dinoz as they could in hopes of an advantageous starting rank. So saying that only after that people should give it their all is inconsistent.
2. A lot of players have limited resources, and can't repeatedly go for broke in the face of every challenge. People need to budget for seven matches, and their potential rewards... and their potential fun.
3. Winning the battle and losing the war, as well as losing the battle and winning the war, are not axiomatically wrong. In fact, taking an unyielding stand on everything regardless of consequences is a hypocritical philosophy, and an impossible ethic... because we all continually violate it throughout our lives, and we would otherwise be long extinct.
4. This is an experimental CotC... if it is flawed (which it is), then sticking our heads in the sand won't lead to a better 3rd CotC.
5. All people don't play for the same reason, nor the same goals, nor the same way. If the system is broken for your playstyle, help fix the system and don't condemn others for playing differently within that system.

On july 8, 2011
alkmona
after many thoughts about the matching system i finally have concluded for me the following:
the matching system itself is good. (yeah - flame me)

here is why: the pairing is basically "fight agains 7 clans who have entered about the same power as your own clan".
so it all depends on how many and which dinoz you selected in the preparation phase which enemies you are facing now.

it seems to me like bidding for a contract: if you lower the price too much you will lose money (lose fights due to lack of power), if you bid too high you will not get the contract (get strong enemies and probably lose the fight).

so if you were lucky and entered a good dinoz-mix you have a good chance of winning at least half of your fights.
and not even being in 1st place at the start prevents you from losing in points (see D&C) when the board is against you.

the thing that I am not sure about is the rewarding. IMO the groups should be rewarded separately (as before in leagues) for number of wins. So all clans with 6 wins should get the same price, disregarding their final position in rank.
if that is the case then I'll quit bitchin and say "Well done MT - you really thought this through"

sorry about the length

On july 11, 2011
Husaurus
The matches are populated starting from Rank 1 on down. So when it get to LBT, LBT has already fought the three clans below it, so it gets matched with Axie Force. This causes EC not to be able to be matched with the clan below it, so it goes down the list and snags RA. This causes GC not to be able to be matched with the clan below it, so it goes down the list and snags DE.

So basically, in Rounds 6 & 7, the bumps to prevent rematches become the dominant factor in the clan pairings. These bumps can cascade changes down the list, but can also absorb the effects of swaps in rank. Most of the battles in contention in Round 6 seem to be of the second type.
